content.checklist_title: Incorporation of Scheme-Specific Information in SID
content.checklist_description: The Scheme Information Document (SID) must incorporate all information pertaining to the particular scheme, following the prescribed format and sequence as mandated by SEBI. This includes details such as scheme objectives, investment pattern, fees, and other scheme-specific disclosures.
content.rationale: To ensure that investors receive comprehensive and standardized information about each mutual fund scheme, facilitating informed investment decisions.

content.checklist_title: Certification of New Scheme by Trustees
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose a certification from the Trustees stating that the scheme is a new product and not a minor modification of an existing scheme. The date of approval by the Trustees must also be disclosed.
content.rationale: To ensure that new schemes are distinctly identified and approved by Trustees, maintaining transparency and regulatory oversight.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Standard Observations in SID and SAI
content.checklist_description: AMCs must incorporate all prescribed standard observations in the SID and Statement of Additional Information (SAI), clearly mentioning the page numbers where each observation is included.
content.rationale: To maintain a minimum level of disclosures and ensure consistency across mutual fund documents.

content.checklist_title: Availability of SID and SAI to Investors and Distributors
content.checklist_description: The SID and SAI must be readily available with all distributors and Investor Service Centres (ISCs). Trustees and AMCs must confirm this availability to SEBI in their half-yearly trustee reports.
content.rationale: To facilitate easy access to scheme information for investors and intermediaries, promoting transparency.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Benchmark Indices in SID
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the benchmark index or indices selected for the scheme, appropriate to the investment objective and portfolio. For equity schemes, recognized indices like BSE Sensex or NSE Nifty should be disclosed; for debt and balanced schemes, suitable indices recommended by AMFI should be used.
content.rationale: To provide investors with a clear basis for evaluating scheme performance relative to an appropriate market benchmark.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Fundamental Attributes in SID
content.checklist_description: The SID must clearly disclose the fundamental attributes of the scheme, including type (open-ended/close-ended/interval), category (equity, debt, hybrid, etc.), investment objectives, tentative asset allocation with minimum and maximum limits, liquidity provisions, fees and expenses, and any guarantees or safety nets.
content.rationale: To ensure investors understand the essential characteristics and risks of the scheme.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure Regarding Restriction on Redemption
content.checklist_description: The SID must prominently and extensively disclose the possibility of restrictions on redemption under exceptional circumstances, the conditions under which such restrictions may be imposed, the maximum duration (not exceeding 10 working days in any 90-day period), and the treatment of redemption requests up to INR 2 lakh.
content.rationale: To protect investors by informing them about potential liquidity constraints and the safeguards in place.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of New Fund Offer (NFO) Period and Related Procedures
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the NFO period, which shall be open for a minimum of three working days (generally 15 days for open and close-ended schemes except ELSS), procedures for deployment of NFO proceeds (e.g., in triparty repo on government securities), and timelines for allotment and dispatch of account statements.
content.rationale: To provide clarity on subscription timelines and fund management during the NFO period.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Procedures and Timelines for Filing and Updation of SID and KIM
content.checklist_description: The SID must reflect the procedures for filing draft and final SID with SEBI, including timelines for SEBI observations, updation of SID and Key Information Memorandum (KIM) at least once every half-year, and the requirement to file updated documents with SEBI and upload on AMC and AMFI websites.
content.rationale: To ensure that investors have access to current and accurate scheme information.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Addendum for Changes in Scheme Details
content.checklist_description: In case of changes to the scheme (other than fundamental attributes), an addendum must be issued and displayed on the AMC website immediately, circulated to distributors and ISCs, and attached to all existing SID and KIM documents until updated versions are issued.
content.rationale: To keep investors and intermediaries informed of material changes in a timely manner.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure Requirements on Conversion of Close-Ended Schemes to Open-Ended Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must be revised and updated to reflect the conversion, including filing a draft SID with SEBI, providing unit holders with a communication containing the latest portfolio, financial performance since inception, and addendum detailing modifications. Unit holders must be given at least 30 days to exit without exit load.
content.rationale: To protect investor interests and ensure transparency during scheme conversion.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure Requirements on Consolidation or Merger of Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose details of the consolidation or merger, including latest portfolio, financial performance since inception, investment objectives, asset allocation, basis of unit allocation with numerical illustration, exposure to below investment grade/default securities and illiquid assets, tax impact, and any other disclosures specified by Trustees or SEBI. Unit holders must be given an exit option at prevailing NAV without exit load.
content.rationale: To ensure investors are fully informed and their interests protected during scheme consolidation or merger.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Launch of Additional Plans
content.checklist_description: For additional plans consistent with existing scheme characteristics, an addendum must be issued containing salient features such as entry/exit loads and expenses. This addendum must be filed with SEBI 21 days prior to launch, and an advertisement or press release must be published at the time of launch.
content.rationale: To maintain transparency and regulatory compliance when launching additional plans under existing schemes.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Single Plan Expense Structure
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the scheme is launched under a single plan with a uniform expense structure applicable to all new investors. Existing schemes with multiple plans must accept fresh subscriptions only under one plan.
content.rationale: To simplify expense structures and ensure fairness among investors.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Direct Plan Details
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the availability of a separate Direct Plan for investments not routed through distributors, specifying that the Direct Plan has a lower expense ratio excluding distribution expenses and commissions, no commission is paid from such plans, and that the Direct Plan has a separate NAV.
content.rationale: To inform investors about the availability and features of Direct Plans, enabling them to make informed investment choices and understand cost benefits.

content.checklist_title: Scheme Categorization and Uniform Description
content.checklist_description: The SID must clearly state the scheme category (Equity, Debt, Hybrid, Solution Oriented, Other) and provide the uniform description of the scheme type as per SEBI categorization norms, including detailed asset allocation and investment strategy characteristics specific to the category.
content.rationale: To ensure uniformity and clarity across mutual fund schemes, enabling investors to compare and evaluate schemes effectively.

content.checklist_title: Minimum Asset Allocation for Equity Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the minimum percentage of investment in equity and equity-related instruments as per the scheme category (e.g., Multi Cap Fund requires minimum 75% equity with specified sub-allocations to large, mid, and small cap stocks).
content.rationale: To provide transparency on the investment mandate and risk profile of the scheme aligned with its category.

content.checklist_title: Minimum Asset Allocation for Debt Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must specify the minimum investment in debt and money market instruments, including Macaulay duration ranges for duration-based schemes, minimum investment in corporate bonds or government securities as applicable, and any specific credit rating requirements.
content.rationale: To inform investors about the debt portfolio composition and risk-return characteristics of the scheme.

content.checklist_title: Lock-in Period for Solution Oriented Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the specified lock-in period applicable to the scheme (e.g., Retirement Fund with lock-in of at least 5 years or till retirement age, whichever is earlier; Children's Fund with lock-in till child attains majority or 5 years), and clarify applicability to new investments, SIPs, and STPs.
content.rationale: To ensure investors are aware of the lock-in restrictions impacting liquidity and investment horizon.

content.checklist_title: Scheme Name to Reflect Category
content.checklist_description: The SID must use the scheme name identical to the scheme category to maintain uniformity and ease of identification by investors.
content.rationale: To avoid confusion and facilitate informed decision-making by investors.

content.checklist_title: Definition and Disclosure of Large Cap, Mid Cap, Small Cap Universe
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the scheme follows SEBI-defined classification of large cap (top 1-100 companies), mid cap (101-250), and small cap (251 onwards) based on full market capitalization as per AMFI's biannual list, and that portfolio rebalancing will be done within one month of list updates.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency and uniformity in investment universe definitions across schemes.

content.checklist_title: Portfolio Rebalancing Timelines and Deviation Disclosure
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the mandated rebalancing period (30 business days for all schemes except Overnight Funds), procedures in case of non-rebalancing including reporting to trustees and investors, and consequences such as prohibition on launching new schemes and waiver of exit load for exiting investors.
content.rationale: To maintain asset allocation discipline and protect investor interests by timely portfolio adjustments.

content.checklist_title: Exclusion of CDMDF Units from Asset Allocation Limits
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that investments in units of Credit Default Mutual Fund Debt (CDMDF) schemes are excluded from the base of net assets for calculating asset allocation limits.
content.rationale: To clarify asset allocation computations and compliance with SEBI guidelines.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Recurring Expenses in Fund of Funds Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that investors bear recurring expenses of the Fund of Funds scheme in addition to expenses of the underlying schemes, and that no revenue sharing or commission is received by the AMC from underlying funds.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency about layered expenses and avoid conflicts of interest.

content.checklist_title: Investment Policy and Limits for Gold ETFs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the scheme primarily invests in gold and gold-related instruments, specify limits on cumulative exposure to gold-related instruments (not exceeding 50% of NAV, with sub-limits for GDS and GMS), and include the AMC's written policy approved by the Board and Trustees regarding such investments.
content.rationale: To inform investors about investment composition and risk controls specific to gold ETFs.

content.checklist_title: Valuation and NAV Calculation Methodology for Gold ETFs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the valuation methodology for gold as per SEBI regulations and the formula for NAV calculation up to four decimal points.
content.rationale: To provide transparency on valuation and NAV computation for investor confidence.

content.checklist_title: Benchmark Disclosure for Gold ETFs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the benchmark for the Gold ETF scheme is the price of gold.
content.rationale: To set investor expectations regarding performance comparison.

content.checklist_title: Half-Yearly Physical Verification and Reporting for Gold ETFs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that physical verification of gold holdings will be conducted by statutory auditors and reported to trustees on a half-yearly basis, and that this confirmation forms part of the half-yearly trustee report to SEBI.
content.rationale: To assure investors of the existence and safekeeping of underlying physical assets.

content.checklist_title: Investment Objective and Limits for Silver ETFs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the scheme aims to generate returns in line with physical silver prices, invests at least 95% in silver and silver-related instruments, specifies limits on exposure to silver ETCDs (not exceeding 10% of NAV), and includes AMC's approved written policy on such investments.
content.rationale: To provide clarity on investment strategy and risk management for silver ETFs.

content.checklist_title: Valuation and NAV Calculation Methodology for Silver ETFs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the valuation methodology for silver as per SEBI regulations and the formula for NAV calculation up to four decimal points.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency in valuation and NAV computation.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Tracking Error and Tracking Difference for ETFs/Index Funds
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the tracking error limits (annualized standard deviation of daily returns difference not exceeding 2% for equity ETFs/Index Funds), tracking difference disclosure on AMC and AMFI websites monthly, and corrective actions in case of breaches.
content.rationale: To inform investors about the scheme's ability to replicate the underlying index or commodity performance.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Market Making and Liquidity Arrangements for ETFs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the appointment of at least two Market Makers, the market making policy including incentive structure, creation unit size, and mechanisms to provide continuous liquidity on stock exchanges.
content.rationale: To assure investors of liquidity and fair pricing in secondary markets.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Indicative NAV (iNAV) for ETFs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that indicative NAV will be published continuously on stock exchanges with specified frequency and time lags depending on the ETF type (equity, debt, gold, silver, international), and that AMC and stock exchanges will have mechanisms for data sharing.
content.rationale: To provide real-time valuation transparency aiding investor decisions.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Portfolio Concentration Norms for Equity ETFs and Index Funds
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the underlying index has minimum 10 stocks, limits on maximum weight of single stock (35% for sectoral/thematic, 25% otherwise), cumulative weight of top three stocks not exceeding 65%, and minimum trading frequency and impact cost criteria for constituents.
content.rationale: To mitigate concentration risk and ensure liquidity in ETF portfolios.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Debt ETFs/Index Funds Constituent and Exposure Norms
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the underlying index constituents have defined credit ratings and maturities, investment grade ratings, issuer-level aggregation for exposure limits, issuer and sector weight limits as per SEBI norms, and periodic review frequency.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency on credit quality, diversification, and risk controls.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Rebalancing Timelines for ETFs/Index Funds
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that portfolio rebalancing due to index constituent changes must be done within 7 calendar days, and rebalancing due to rating downgrades within 30 calendar days, with provisions for segregated portfolios if securities fall below investment grade.
content.rationale: To maintain alignment with the underlying index and manage credit risk.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Capital Protection Oriented Scheme Characteristics
content.checklist_description: The SID must clearly state that the scheme is oriented towards capital protection and not guaranteed returns, indicate that capital protection arises from portfolio structure and not from any bank guarantee or insurance, and disclose the credit rating of the proposed portfolio structure along with quarterly reviews.
content.rationale: To prevent investor misperception about guarantees and ensure transparency on risk.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Guaranteed Return Schemes Guarantee Details
content.checklist_description: The SID must clearly disclose who is offering the guarantee and that the guarantee covers both the initial capital invested and the assured returns.
content.rationale: To provide clarity on the nature and source of guarantees to investors.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Real Estate Mutual Fund Investment Locations
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that investments in real estate mutual fund schemes will be made only in cities listed as Million Plus Urban Agglomerations or Million Plus Cities as per SEBI guidelines.
content.rationale: To inform investors about geographical investment restrictions and risk concentration.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of ESG Scheme Strategy in Scheme Name
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds must clearly disclose the ESG strategy adopted by the scheme in the scheme name itself, e.g., 'XYZ ESG Exclusionary Strategy Fund' or 'ABC ESG Best-in-class Strategy Fund'.
content.rationale: To enable investors to identify the ESG strategy of the scheme easily and make informed investment decisions, thereby preventing greenwashing.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of ESG Scores in Monthly Portfolio Statements
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds shall disclose security-wise BRSR Core scores and BRSR scores as provided by SEBI registered ESG Rating Providers (ERPs) in the monthly portfolio statements of ESG schemes. The name of the ERP providing ESG scores must also be disclosed, and any change in ERP must be explained in the next monthly portfolio statement.
content.rationale: To enhance transparency and provide investors with decision-useful information on ESG performance of securities held by the scheme.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Voting Rationale for ESG Schemes
content.checklist_description: AMCs must disclose on their website quarterly the votes cast by ESG schemes on investee companies’ resolutions, including the specific rationale for voting decisions. The rationale must categorically state whether the resolution was supported or opposed due to environmental, social, or governance reasons. If voting approaches differ between ESG and non-ESG schemes, disclosures must be made separately.
content.rationale: To enhance transparency on stewardship activities and demonstrate alignment of voting decisions with ESG principles.

content.checklist_title: Annual Fund Manager Commentary and Case Studies for ESG Schemes
content.checklist_description: The Annual Report of ESG schemes must include a Fund Manager Commentary detailing how the ESG strategy was applied, engagements with portfolio companies, escalation strategies, tracking of ESG rating movements, and case studies of engagements and voting exercises. Commentary must also disclose percentage of AUM invested in companies without BRSR disclosures and reasons for any change in ESG Rating Provider.
content.rationale: To provide investors with qualitative insights on ESG implementation and engagement outcomes, improving transparency and accountability.

content.checklist_title: Assurance and Board Certification on ESG Scheme Compliance
content.checklist_description: AMCs must obtain independent reasonable assurance annually on the ESG scheme’s portfolio compliance with stated strategy and objectives, and disclose this assurance in the scheme’s annual report. The Board of AMCs must certify compliance with regulatory requirements and disclosures based on an internal ESG audit, and disclose this certification in the annual report.
content.rationale: To ensure credibility and reliability of ESG disclosures and compliance through independent verification and board oversight.

content.checklist_title: Portfolio Disclosure Frequency and Format
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds/AMCs must disclose scheme portfolios (with ISINs) on their websites and AMFI’s website within 10 days of month/half-year end in a user-friendly, downloadable spreadsheet format. Debt schemes must disclose portfolios fortnightly within 5 days of each fortnight. Yield of instruments must also be disclosed. Monthly and half-yearly portfolio statements must be emailed to unit holders with registered emails.
content.rationale: To provide timely and accessible portfolio information to investors for informed decision-making.

content.checklist_title: Half-Yearly Disclosure of Derivative Investments
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds must disclose investments in derivative instruments in half-yearly portfolio disclosures, annual reports, or other disclosures using the prescribed uniform format. Margin amounts paid should be reported separately under cash or bank balances.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency and uniformity in disclosure of derivative exposures.

content.checklist_title: Unaudited Half-Yearly Financial Results Disclosure
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds must publish unaudited half-yearly financial results in the prescribed format on AMFI’s website within one month of half-year end. The disclosures should be in a user-friendly, downloadable format (preferably spreadsheet).
content.rationale: To keep investors informed about the financial performance of schemes in a timely and accessible manner.

content.checklist_title: Annual Report and Abridged Summary Disclosure and Distribution
content.checklist_description: Scheme-wise annual reports or abridged summaries must be hosted prominently on Mutual Fund/AMC and AMFI websites. They must be emailed to unit holders with registered emails. For others, Mutual Funds must send letters with self-addressed envelopes for opting-in to receive physical copies. A second communication round must be conducted for non-respondents. Advertisements must be published annually in two national newspapers (English and Hindi) informing about availability and modes to request reports. Physical copies must be provided free of cost on request. The opt-in facility must also be provided in new subscriber application forms.
content.rationale: To ensure wide dissemination of scheme performance information and respect investor preferences for receiving reports.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Large Unit Holdings
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds must disclose the number of investors holding over 25% of the NAV in a scheme and their total holdings as a percentage in the Statement of Accounts issued after the NFO and in Half Yearly and Annual Results.
content.rationale: To provide transparency on concentration risk and significant holdings in schemes.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Asset Under Management (AUM) Details
content.checklist_description: AMCs must disclose on their websites and to AMFI monthly AUM figures bifurcated by scheme categories (equity, debt, balanced, etc.) and by geography (top 5 cities, next 10 cities, next 20 cities, next 75 cities, others). Additional disclosures include monthly AAUM from different scheme categories, contributions from B-30 and T-30 cities, sponsor and non-sponsor groups, investor types, and state-wise/UT-wise contributions. AMFI consolidates and publishes industry-wide data. Disclosures must be in spreadsheet format and submitted within 7 working days from month-end.
content.rationale: To provide comprehensive and granular data on AUM distribution for market analysis and investor information.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Distributor Commission and Expenses
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds/AMCs must disclose on their websites the total commission and expenses paid to distributors who meet specified criteria.
content.rationale: To enhance transparency on distribution costs and conflicts of interest.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Segregated Portfolio Provisions in SID
content.checklist_description: For schemes permitting creation of segregated portfolios due to credit events, the Scheme Information Document (SID) must include enabling provisions with detailed disclosures. This includes the process, impact on investors, and conditions under which segregated portfolios may be created.
content.rationale: To ensure investors are informed upfront about the possibility and implications of segregated portfolios.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure Requirements upon Creation of Segregated Portfolio
content.checklist_description: Upon creation of a segregated portfolio, Mutual Funds must communicate to investors a statement of holdings indicating units held in segregated and main portfolios along with NAVs within 5 working days. Adequate disclosures must appear in all scheme documents, monthly/half-yearly portfolio disclosures, and annual reports. The number of segregated portfolios must be prominently disclosed in all relevant documents and websites. Scheme performance disclosures must reflect the impact of segregated portfolios with footnotes on NAV fall and recoveries. These disclosures must continue for at least 3 years after full recovery or write-off.
content.rationale: To enable investors to make informed decisions and understand the impact of credit events on their investments.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Swing Pricing Framework in SID and Annual Reports
content.checklist_description: AMCs must disclose detailed information on the swing pricing framework in the Scheme Information Document (SID) and Statement of Additional Information (SAI), including how it works, triggering conditions, and impact on NAV for incoming and outgoing investors. Disclosures must also be made in scheme-wise Annual Reports and abridged summaries, including periods of applicability, unswung NAV, swing factor applied, and whether the swing is optional or mandatory.
content.rationale: To ensure investors understand the swing pricing mechanism and its effect on their investments.

content.checklist_title: Fund Manager Tenure and Name Disclosure
content.checklist_description: The Scheme Information Document (SID) must disclose the tenure for which the fund manager has been managing the scheme along with the name(s) of the scheme’s fund manager(s).
content.rationale: To improve transparency and provide investors with information about the experience and continuity of the fund management team.

content.checklist_title: Scheme Portfolio Holdings Disclosure via Web Link
content.checklist_description: The SID must provide a functional web link where the scheme’s portfolio holdings (top 10 holdings by issuer and fund allocation towards various sectors) are hosted and accessible.
content.rationale: To facilitate ease of access and transparency of portfolio composition without overloading the SID document.

content.checklist_title: Expense Ratio of Underlying Schemes for FoF
content.checklist_description: In case of Fund of Funds (FoF) schemes, the SID must disclose the expense ratio of the underlying scheme(s).
content.rationale: To enable investors to understand the total cost structure including expenses at the underlying scheme level.

content.checklist_title: Scheme Portfolio Turnover Ratio Disclosure
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the scheme’s portfolio turnover ratio.
content.rationale: To inform investors about the frequency of portfolio changes which impacts transaction costs and tax implications.

content.checklist_title: Aggregate Investment by Fund Manager(s) Disclosure
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the aggregate investment in the scheme by the concerned scheme’s fund manager(s).
content.rationale: To demonstrate alignment of interests between fund managers and investors.

content.checklist_title: Aggregate Investment by AMC Board and Key Personnel in SAI
content.checklist_description: The Statement of Additional Information (SAI) must disclose the aggregate investment in the scheme by the AMC’s Board of Directors and other key personnel.
content.rationale: To provide transparency on investments by AMC’s senior management and key personnel, indicating their confidence in the scheme.

content.checklist_title: Illustration of Expense Ratio Impact on Returns
content.checklist_description: The SID must include an illustration showing the impact of the expense ratio on the scheme’s returns by providing a simple example.
content.rationale: To help investors understand how expenses affect their net returns.

content.checklist_title: Separate SID/KIM Availability on Website
content.checklist_description: A separate Scheme Information Document (SID) and Key Information Memorandum (KIM) for each mutual fund scheme managed by the AMC must be made available on the mutual fund’s and AMC’s websites.
content.rationale: To ensure easy access and availability of scheme-specific information for investors.

content.checklist_title: AMC Website Dashboard for Scheme Disclosures
content.checklist_description: Each AMC must maintain a dashboard on its website providing performance and key disclosures for each scheme, including scheme’s AUM, investment objective, expense ratios, portfolio details, and past performance. The data should be in a comparable, downloadable, and machine-readable format.
content.rationale: To enhance transparency and facilitate investor comparison and analysis.

content.checklist_title: Scheme Performance Disclosure on AMFI Website
content.checklist_description: AMCs must disclose scheme returns vis-à-vis benchmark returns (Total Return Index) in terms of CAGR for periods of 1, 3, 5, 10 years and since inception on the AMFI website. For certain short-term schemes, performance for 7 days, 15 days, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months must also be disclosed. This disclosure must be updated daily based on previous day NAV and be investor-friendly with filtering and sorting features.
content.rationale: To provide investors with standardized, timely, and comprehensive performance data for informed decision-making.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Scheme AUM and NAV on AMFI Website
content.checklist_description: Scheme AUM (excluding overnight and liquid schemes) and previous day NAV must be disclosed on AMFI website daily. For overnight and liquid schemes, closing AUM and AAUM of the previous month must be disclosed daily, with additional disclosure triggered if AUM movement exceeds 10%.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency about the size and valuation of schemes, especially for liquid and overnight funds where AUM can fluctuate significantly.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Distributor-wise Commission and Inflows
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds/AMCs must disclose on their websites yearly distributor-wise gross inflows (indicating if the distributor is an associate or group company of the sponsor), net inflows, average AUM, and ratio of AUM to gross inflows. Excessive portfolio turnover by distributors requires additional due diligence by AMCs.
content.rationale: To promote transparency in distribution commissions and monitor distributor activities for investor protection.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Brokerage and Commission Paid to Associates
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds must disclose brokerage and commission paid to associates/related parties/group companies of sponsor/AMC in unaudited half-yearly financial results, abridged scheme-wise annual report, and SAI in prescribed formats.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency and regulatory compliance regarding payments to related parties.

content.checklist_title: Risk-o-Meter Disclosure in SID and Promotional Material
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds/AMCs must disclose the risk-o-meter of the scheme wherever scheme performance is disclosed, including promotional materials. The risk-o-meter of the scheme and its benchmark must be disclosed wherever performance vis-à-vis benchmark is shown. The risk-o-meter of the benchmark must be disclosed on the front page of the initial application form, SID, KIM, and common application form.
content.rationale: To provide investors with a standardized risk assessment tool for better understanding of scheme risk profiles.

content.checklist_title: Portfolio Details and Risk-o-Meter in Investor Communications
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds/AMCs must send scheme portfolio details along with scheme risk-o-meter, benchmark name, and benchmark risk-o-meter in fortnightly, monthly, and half-yearly portfolio statements via email to unitholders invested in the scheme.
content.rationale: To keep investors informed about their investments and associated risks on a regular basis.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investor Complaints
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds must disclose details of investor complaints received from all sources on their websites, AMFI website, and in their Annual Reports. The complaint details on websites must be updated monthly by the 7th of the succeeding month. Annual report disclosures must be vetted and signed off by Trustees.
content.rationale: To enhance investor awareness and confidence by providing transparency on grievance redressal.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investor Charter
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds must disclose the Investor Charter on their websites, make it available at prominent places in their offices, and bring it to the notice of existing and new unitholders.
content.rationale: To educate investors about their rights, services provided, and grievance redressal mechanisms.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Contact Details Update Efforts
content.checklist_description: AMCs must make continuous efforts to update email IDs and mobile numbers of all unit holders for communication via emails and SMS.
content.rationale: To ensure effective and timely communication with investors.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Bio-data of Key Personnel
content.checklist_description: AMCs must submit the bio-data of all key personnel (including CEO, CIO, CRO, CISO, COO, Fund Managers, Compliance Officer, Sales Head, Investor Relations Officers, heads of departments, dealers, and others identified by AMC and Trustees) to Trustees and the Board. The bio-data format is prescribed.
content.rationale: To provide transparency on the qualifications and experience of personnel managing the mutual fund.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Executive Remuneration
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds/AMCs must disclose on their websites under a separate 'Remuneration' head the name, designation, and remuneration of CEO, CIO, COO, top ten employees by remuneration, and any employee whose annual remuneration exceeds Rs.1.02 crore or monthly remuneration exceeds Rs.8.5 lakh (if employed part of the year). Also disclose the ratio of CEO’s remuneration to median remuneration of employees and total AAUM (debt and equity) with growth over last three years. Disclosures must be made within one month from end of financial year.
content.rationale: To promote transparency in remuneration policies and alignment with investor interests.

content.checklist_title: Annual Report of AMC Availability
content.checklist_description: The annual report containing accounts of the AMC must be displayed on mutual fund websites immediately after approval in Annual General Meetings, within four months from the financial year-end. The annual report must mention that unitholders may request the AMC’s annual report. The report must be available in machine-readable format.
content.rationale: To ensure timely availability of AMC’s financial information to investors.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Minimum Number of Investors and Holding Limits
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that each open-ended scheme/plan shall have a minimum of 20 investors and no single investor shall hold more than 25% of the scheme's corpus. For close-ended and interval schemes, these conditions apply at the time of allotment. The SID should also disclose the consequences of breach, including automatic redemption or winding up of the scheme.
content.rationale: To ensure diversification of investor base and prevent concentration risk, thereby protecting investor interests as per SEBI Circulars dated December 12, 2003 and June 14, 2005.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Minimum Subscription and AUM Requirements for Debt Oriented Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must specify the minimum subscription amount at NFO for debt oriented and balanced schemes (at least INR 20 crore) and other schemes (at least INR 10 crore), with exceptions for ETFs and Index Funds. It should also disclose the requirement to maintain an average AUM of INR 20 crore on a half-yearly rolling basis and the consequences of non-compliance.
content.rationale: To ensure adequate corpus for debt schemes to meet investment objectives and regulatory compliance, safeguarding investor interests as per SEBI Circular dated June 20, 2014 and subsequent updates.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Scheme Performance Benchmarking to Total Return Index (TRI)
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the benchmark selected for the scheme aligned with its investment objective and strategy, specifying that performance will be benchmarked against the Total Return variant of the index. Where TRI data is unavailable for the entire period, a composite CAGR using Price Return Index (PRI) and TRI shall be used, with appropriate explanatory disclosure.
content.rationale: To provide investors with a more accurate and comprehensive basis for performance comparison, reflecting both capital gains and income, as mandated by SEBI Circular dated April 12, 2021.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of AMC's Investment in its Own Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the minimum percentage of assets under management (AUM) that the AMC is required to invest in its own schemes based on the risk level of the scheme, as per the risk-o-meter classification. It should also disclose the AMC's policy on maintaining such investments throughout the scheme tenure and the monitoring mechanism.
content.rationale: To align the interests of the AMC with those of the unitholders, ensuring AMC's skin in the game, as per SEBI Circulars dated June 12, 2020 and September 2, 2021.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Designated Employees' Mandatory Investment in Mutual Fund Units
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that designated employees of the AMC are required to invest a minimum percentage (20%) of their gross annual compensation (net of taxes and statutory contributions) in units of the schemes they manage or oversee. It should detail the phased implementation for junior employees, lock-in period (minimum 3 years or scheme tenure), investment options, redemption restrictions, and clawback provisions in case of misconduct.
content.rationale: To align the interests of AMC's key personnel with those of unitholders, promoting responsible management and reducing conflicts of interest, as per SEBI Circulars dated April 28, 2021 and subsequent clarifications.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Unit Holder Protection Committee (UHPC) Constitution and Mandate
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the constitution of the UHPC by the AMC, its responsibilities including protection of unit holders' interests, ensuring sound market practices, compliance with laws, investor education, grievance redressal, and reporting mechanisms to the AMC board.
content.rationale: To enhance investor protection and governance through a dedicated committee overseeing unit holder interests, as mandated by SEBI Circular dated July 7, 2023.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of AMC's Corporate Governance and Voting Policies
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the AMC's general policies and procedures for exercising voting rights on shares held by the mutual fund, including disclosure of actual voting on key matters such as corporate governance, capital structure changes, stock option plans, social responsibility, appointment/removal of directors, and related party transactions. It should also disclose the rationale for voting decisions and availability of voting records on the AMC's website.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency and accountability in the exercise of voting rights, promoting better corporate governance in investee companies, as per SEBI Circulars dated March 15, 2010 and subsequent updates.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Participation in Derivatives and Associated Risks
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the extent and manner of the scheme's participation in derivatives markets, including position limits, risk factors, and numerical examples explaining such risks. For schemes not originally envisaging derivatives, prior disclosure and a 30-day exit option without exit load must be provided to unitholders before commencing derivatives trading.
content.rationale: To inform investors about the use of derivatives and associated risks, ensuring informed investment decisions and regulatory compliance, as per SEBI Circulars dated September 14, 2005 and February 20, 2017.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Systems Audit Framework and Compliance
content.checklist_description: The SID or associated documents must disclose that the AMC and Mutual Fund undergo annual systems audits by independent qualified auditors covering front office, back office, fund accounting, unit-holder servicing, regulatory compliance, and access controls. It should mention the reporting of exceptions to the Technology Committee, AMC and Trustee Boards, and submission of audit reports to SEBI.
content.rationale: To ensure robust operational controls and safeguard investor interests through standardized systems audit, as per SEBI Circular dated April 11, 2019.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Minimum Investor Base and Concentration Risk Monitoring
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the requirement of maintaining a minimum investor base of 20 and that no single investor should hold more than 25% of the scheme corpus. It should explain the monitoring mechanism for breaches, rebalancing periods, notices for redemption, and consequences of non-compliance including automatic redemption or winding up.
content.rationale: To maintain diversification and reduce concentration risk, protecting investor interests, as per SEBI Circulars dated December 12, 2003 and June 14, 2005.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Listing and Trading of Units in Schemes Under Winding Up
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that units of schemes under winding up may be listed and traded on recognized stock exchanges as an optional exit route for investors. It should specify that trading will initially be in dematerialized form, transfer facilitation by AMC, and restrictions on transactions by AMC, sponsor, employees, and trustees during winding up.
content.rationale: To provide liquidity options to investors during scheme winding up while ensuring regulatory compliance and preventing conflicts of interest, as per SEBI Circular dated May 20, 2020.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of NAV and Timelines
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds/AMCs must prominently disclose the Net Asset Values (NAVs) of all schemes under a separate head on their respective websites and on the AMFI website. They must also provide facility to send latest NAVs to unit holders via SMS upon request. NAVs for all schemes except Fund of Fund schemes must be updated by 11:00 p.m. on the same day, and Fund of Fund schemes by 10 a.m. the following business day. Any delay beyond these timelines must be explained in writing to AMFI and reported in quarterly Compliance Test Reports (CTRs) with reasons and corrective actions taken.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency and timely dissemination of NAV information to investors, enabling informed investment decisions and compliance with Regulation 48 of SEBI (Mutual Funds) Regulations, 1996.

content.checklist_title: Explanation of NAV Calculation Methodology
content.checklist_description: Mutual Funds/AMCs must explain the methodology of calculating the sale and repurchase price of units with a simple numerical example at all relevant places such as their websites, AMFI website, and Scheme Information Documents (SIDs).
content.rationale: To make the calculation of sale and repurchase prices comprehensible to investors and maintain uniformity in pricing.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Delay in NAV Publication
content.checklist_description: In case NAVs are not available before commencement of business hours on the following day due to any reason, Mutual Funds must issue a press release giving reasons for the delay and explain when the NAVs will be published.
content.rationale: To maintain investor confidence and transparency regarding NAV availability.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of NAV Timelines for Overseas Schemes
content.checklist_description: For schemes investing overseas, the SID must disclose the applicable timelines for NAV declaration based on the investment objective and asset allocation, including extended timelines where applicable. The NAV must be disclosed based on the value of underlying securities as on the transaction date.
content.rationale: To address difficulties due to time zone differences and ensure investors are aware of NAV declaration timelines.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of NAV Rounding Policy
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the rounding off policy of NAVs: up to four decimal places for index funds and debt-oriented schemes, and up to two decimal places for equity-oriented and balanced funds. If rounding off to more than two decimal places is adopted for equity or balanced funds, this must be disclosed in the SID or Statement of Additional Information (SAI).
content.rationale: To ensure uniformity and transparency in NAV presentation.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Uniform Cut-off Timings for NAV Applicability
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the uniform cut-off timings applicable for purchase, sale, switch-in, and switch-out transactions for various schemes, including liquid funds, overnight funds, and other schemes. It must also disclose the official points of acceptance where applications are received and the time stamping process for applications.
content.rationale: To provide clarity to investors on the applicable NAV for transactions and ensure fair treatment of all investors.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Time Stamping Procedures
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that applications for purchase and redemption will be time stamped at official points of acceptance with running serial numbers, date, and time. It must also disclose the safeguards for time stamping machines including tamper-proof seals, maintenance procedures, and alternative stamping methods during breakdowns.
content.rationale: To ensure integrity and auditability of transaction timing, preventing manipulation and ensuring compliance.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Sale and Repurchase Price Calculation Methodology
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the uniform method for calculating sale and repurchase prices of units, including the formula: Sale Price = Applicable NAV; Repurchase Price = Applicable NAV * (1 – Exit Load, if any). Exit loads must be charged as a percentage of NAV.
content.rationale: To avoid variation in amounts payable or units allotted and to make calculations transparent and comprehensible.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Intra-day NAV for ETFs
content.checklist_description: For Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs), the SID must disclose that intra-day NAV based on executed prices of underlying securities or commodities will be applicable for transactions directly with AMCs by Authorized Participants or large investors.
content.rationale: To inform investors about the pricing mechanism applicable for direct ETF transactions.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation Methodology for Non-Traded and Thinly Traded Securities
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the valuation norms for non-traded and thinly traded securities, including the use of net worth per share, discounted industry average P/E ratio, and illiquidity discount. It must also disclose the appointment of independent valuers if a security exceeds 5% of scheme assets.
content.rationale: To ensure fair and consistent valuation of illiquid securities and protect investor interests.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation Methodology for Debt and Money Market Securities
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the valuation methodology for money market and debt securities, including amortization-based valuation for securities with residual maturity up to 30 days, use of security-level prices from valuation agencies for longer maturities, and the waterfall approach adopted by valuation agencies.
content.rationale: To maintain uniformity, accuracy, and transparency in valuation of debt instruments.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Deviations from Valuation Agency Prices
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that if the AMC deviates from the valuation prices provided by valuation agencies, the detailed rationale, security details, price differences, and impact on NAV will be recorded, reported to the Board and Trustees, and disclosed prominently on the AMC’s website with links provided in portfolio statements.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency and accountability in valuation practices.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation and Treatment of Below Investment Grade and Default Securities
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the valuation approach for below investment grade and default securities, including use of indicative haircuts, consideration of traded prices if lower, reporting of deviations with rationale, and treatment of accrued interest and future recoveries.
content.rationale: To provide clarity on valuation of higher risk securities and ensure consistent treatment across schemes.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation Methodology for Securities with Put/Call Options
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the valuation methodology for securities with embedded put and/or call options, including valuation at lower or higher of values to maturity or option dates, treatment of multiple options, and requirement for justification if put options are not exercised when favorable.
content.rationale: To ensure accurate valuation reflecting embedded options and protect investor interests.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation of Perpetual Bonds
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that perpetual bonds will be valued treating maturity as 100 years from issuance, with valuation of call/put options as per guidelines, and Macaulay Duration calculated based on deemed residual maturity as per Basel III framework.
content.rationale: To standardize valuation of perpetual bonds and align with regulatory frameworks.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation of Government Securities
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that government securities, including T-bills, will be valued based on security-level prices obtained from valuation agencies irrespective of residual maturity.
content.rationale: To ensure uniform and transparent valuation of government securities.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation of Other Money Market Instruments and OTC Derivatives
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that bills purchased under rediscounting schemes will be valued as per money market guidelines, short-term bank deposits and repo transactions up to 30 days will be valued on cost plus accrual basis, and prices for OTC derivatives and market-linked debentures will be obtained from valuation agencies.
content.rationale: To maintain uniformity and accuracy in valuation of various money market and derivative instruments.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Illiquid Securities Limits and Reporting
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that aggregate value of illiquid securities (non-traded, thinly traded, unlisted equity shares) shall not exceed 15% of total scheme assets, with any excess assigned zero value. It must also disclose that illiquid securities will be marked with an asterisk in portfolio disclosures as of March 31 and September 30 each year.
content.rationale: To limit exposure to illiquid assets and ensure investor awareness of such holdings.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Restrictions on Transfer of Illiquid Securities
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that AMCs are prohibited from transferring illiquid securities among their schemes.
content.rationale: To prevent potential misuse and ensure fair valuation across schemes.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation Methodology for Investment in Unlisted Equity Shares
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the valuation methodology for unlisted equity shares based on audited balance sheet data, net worth calculations considering outstanding warrants/options, discounted industry average P/E ratio, and illiquidity discount. It must also disclose conditions such as zero valuation if audited accounts are unavailable beyond nine months or if net worth is negative, and appointment of independent valuers if exposure exceeds 5% of scheme assets.
content.rationale: To ensure uniformity, transparency, and due diligence in valuation of unlisted equity investments.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Due Diligence and Investment Parameters for Unlisted Equity Shares
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the Board of AMC and Trustees lay down parameters for investing in unlisted equity shares, exercise due diligence before investment, and review performance periodically.
content.rationale: To ensure prudent investment decisions and oversight for unlisted equity investments.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Reporting on Compliance for Unlisted Equity Investments
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that AMCs and Trustees will indicate comments on compliance with unlisted equity investment guidelines in their Compliance Test Reports (CTRs) and Half Yearly Reports filed with SEBI.
content.rationale: To maintain regulatory oversight and transparency on compliance.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Valuation Approach for Securities Not Covered Under Current Policy
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that if securities purchased do not fall under existing valuation frameworks, AMCs will report immediately to AMFI, limit exposure to 5% of scheme AUM, and value such securities using proprietary models approved by independent trustees and auditors until valuation agencies cover them.
content.rationale: To ensure proper valuation and regulatory reporting for new or unusual securities.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Prohibition on Use of Own Trades for Valuation
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that Mutual Funds shall not use their own trades of relatively small quantity for valuation of debt and money market securities or for inter-scheme transfers.
content.rationale: To prevent misuse and manipulation of valuation prices.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Inter-Scheme Transfer Pricing Methodology
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that prices for inter-scheme transfers of money market and debt securities will be obtained from valuation agencies within a specified turnaround time (TAT). If multiple prices are received, an average will be used; if only one price is received, that price will be used; if none are received, AMCs may determine the price as per SEBI regulations.
content.rationale: To ensure fair and consistent pricing for inter-scheme transfers.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Reporting and Dissemination of Debt and Money Market Transactions
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that AMCs will provide daily transaction details, including inter-scheme transfers, of money market and debt securities to the agency providing benchmark yields. Additionally, details of such transactions will be disclosed on the AMC’s website and forwarded to AMFI.
content.rationale: To improve uniformity, accuracy, and transparency in valuation and investor information.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Changes in Terms of Investment
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that any changes to investment terms, including maturity extensions of money market or debt securities, will be reported immediately to valuation agencies and CRAs with reasons. Extensions in maturity will result in the security being treated as 'Default' for valuation purposes. Shortening followed by extension of maturity will also be treated as 'Default'. Any put option inserted post-issuance will not be considered for valuation.
content.rationale: To maintain accurate valuation reflecting credit events and changes in investment terms.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Fees and Expenses Charged to the Scheme
content.checklist_description: The Scheme Information Document (SID) must clearly identify and disclose all expenses charged to the scheme, including AMC fees, trustee fees, and other permissible expenses within regulatory limits. Any additional expenses charged with trustee approval must also be disclosed.
content.rationale: Trustees and AMCs are required to exercise due diligence to ensure all expenses charged to the scheme are clearly identified and disclosed in the offer document, conforming to Regulation 52 of SEBI Mutual Funds Regulations.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Total Expense Ratio (TER)
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the Total Expense Ratio (TER) of the scheme prominently, including base TER and any additional expenses. Any changes in base TER compared to previous TER must be communicated to investors via email or SMS at least three working days prior to the change and updated on AMC and AMFI websites.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency and investor awareness, AMCs must disclose TER daily and notify investors of any changes in base TER as per SEBI circulars dated February 5, 2018, June 5, 2018, and March 25, 2019.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Load Structure and Commission to Distributors
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that there is no entry load for all mutual fund schemes. It must also state that upfront commission to distributors will be paid directly by investors based on service assessment. The load balances must be maintained as liabilities and usage of load balances must be disclosed. Distributors must disclose all commissions payable to them for competing schemes.
content.rationale: To empower investors in commission decisions and ensure transparency in load and commission structures, SEBI mandates these disclosures effective from August 1, 2009.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Transaction Charges
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the applicable transaction charges payable to distributors for subscriptions of Rs. 10,000 and above, differentiating between new and existing investors. It should also state that no transaction charges apply to direct investments or subscriptions below Rs. 10,000.
content.rationale: To ensure investors are informed about transaction charges and to prevent malpractices, SEBI requires these disclosures as per circular dated August 22, 2011.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure on No Load on Bonus Units and Dividend Reinvestment Units
content.checklist_description: The SID must clearly disclose that no entry or exit load will be charged on bonus units and units allotted on reinvestment of dividends.
content.rationale: To maintain uniformity and investor protection, SEBI mandates this disclosure as per circular dated March 18, 2008.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Dividend Distribution Policy and Procedure
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the naming conventions for dividend options (Payout, Reinvestment, Transfer Plan), clarify that dividends may be paid out of investor capital (Equalization Reserve), and explain the segregation between income and capital distribution in statements. For unlisted schemes, the SID must disclose the process for dividend declaration, including trustee decision, record date, and public notice requirements.
content.rationale: To ensure investor clarity on dividend options and procedures, SEBI requires these disclosures to promote transparency and uniformity in dividend distribution.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investment Restrictions and Limits
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose detailed investment restrictions including limits on investment in unlisted debt instruments, unrated debt, instruments with special features (e.g., Basel III bonds), structured obligations/credit enhancements, and sector/group exposure limits. It must also disclose any grandfathering provisions applicable to existing investments.
content.rationale: To ensure investor protection and regulatory compliance, SEBI mandates disclosure of investment restrictions and limits as per various circulars and regulations.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Securities Lending Policy
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the intention to lend securities, exposure limits for securities lending per scheme and per intermediary, and associated risk factors such as loss or bankruptcy. It should also mention reporting and review mechanisms by AMC and Trustees.
content.rationale: To enable informed investor decisions and risk awareness, SEBI requires these disclosures under securities lending guidelines.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Goods and Services Tax (GST) Charges
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that GST on investment and advisory fees may be charged in addition to the maximum TER limit, while GST on other fees shall be borne within the TER limits. GST on exit load shall be paid out of exit load proceeds.
content.rationale: To clarify tax treatment and charges to investors, SEBI mandates these disclosures as per applicable taxation laws.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Brokerage and Transaction Costs
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that brokerage and transaction costs for trade execution are charged to the scheme within prescribed limits (up to 12 bps for cash market and 5 bps for derivatives). Any soft-dollar arrangements providing benefits to AMC must be disclosed if in the interest of investors.
content.rationale: To maintain transparency in costs charged to schemes and ensure investor interests, SEBI requires these disclosures.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investor Education and Awareness Initiatives
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the AMC's commitment to allocate at least 2 basis points of daily net assets for investor education and awareness initiatives, except for ETFs/Index Funds and certain Fund of Funds. It should also mention any industry-level initiatives including celebrity endorsements with SEBI approval.
content.rationale: To promote investor awareness and education, SEBI mandates disclosure of such initiatives and related expenses.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Filing Fees
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose applicable filing fees as per the Second Schedule of SEBI (Mutual Funds) Regulations, 1996 for offer documents and placement memoranda.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency on regulatory fees, SEBI requires disclosure of filing fees.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Exit Load Parity
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that exit loads shall be applied uniformly to all unit holders without distinction based on subscription amount and that any imposition or enhancement of exit load applies only to prospective investments.
content.rationale: To ensure fairness and uniformity in exit load application, SEBI mandates this disclosure.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Borrowing Costs Treatment
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that borrowing costs shall be adjusted against portfolio yield and any borrowing costs exceeding portfolio yield shall be borne by the AMC.
content.rationale: To clarify cost treatment and protect investor interests, SEBI requires this disclosure.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investment in Index Funds
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that investments by index funds will be in accordance with the weightage of the scrips in the specific index as disclosed, and for sectoral schemes, the upper ceiling on investments will be based on sectoral index weightage or 10% of NAV, whichever is higher.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency in index fund investment strategy, SEBI mandates this disclosure.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investment Policy for Liquid Schemes
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that liquid fund schemes will invest only in debt and money market securities with maturity up to 91 days, including details on calculation of maturity for securities with multiple payouts or put/call options.
content.rationale: To ensure compliance with investment restrictions and inform investors, SEBI requires this disclosure.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Credit Risk Based Single Issuer Limits
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose credit rating based single issuer limits for debt and money market instruments, specifying limits for AAA, AA, and A rated securities, and conditions for extension of limits with board approval.
content.rationale: To manage concentration risk and ensure investor protection, SEBI mandates disclosure of these prudential limits.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Portfolio Concentration Risk Limits
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose sectoral exposure limits (20% of net assets excluding certain securities), additional exposure to Housing Finance Companies with conditions, group exposure limits, and definitions of group companies. It must also disclose any grandfathering provisions and that trustees review exposures periodically.
content.rationale: To ensure risk diversification and investor awareness, SEBI requires detailed disclosure of concentration risk limits.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investment in Non-Convertible Preference Shares (NCPS)
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that NCPS are treated as debt instruments and that all investment restrictions applicable to debt instruments apply to NCPS as well.
content.rationale: To clarify treatment and applicable restrictions, SEBI mandates this disclosure.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Approval Process for Investment in Unrated Debt Instruments
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that AMCs have constituted committees to approve investments in unrated instruments based on parameters approved by the AMC and Trustees, and that any investments outside parameters require prior board and trustee approval.
content.rationale: To ensure governance and risk management in unrated investments, SEBI requires disclosure of approval processes.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Funds Parked in Short Term Deposits
content.checklist_description: Half yearly portfolio statements must disclose all funds parked in short term deposits under a separate heading. Details to be disclosed include the name of the bank, amount of funds parked, and percentage of NAV.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency regarding the parking of funds in short term deposits pending deployment, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF2/CIR/P/2019/101 dated September 20, 2019.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Repo Transactions in Corporate Debt Securities
content.checklist_description: The Scheme Information Document (SID) must disclose: (a) the intention to participate in repo transactions in corporate debt securities as per RBI and SEBI directions; (b) the exposure limit for the scheme; and (c) the risk factors associated with repo transactions in corporate bonds.
content.rationale: To enable investors to make informed decisions about repo transactions in corporate debt securities, as mandated by SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF/19/2011 dated November 11, 2011.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Overseas Investment Intent and Details
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the intention to invest in overseas securities and/or ETFs, the attendant risk factors and returns, how such investments further the scheme's investment objectives, the name of the dedicated fund manager for overseas investments, and the exposure limits (percentage of assets to be invested overseas).
content.rationale: To ensure investors are aware of overseas investment plans, associated risks, and management, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/IMD/CIR No.7/104753/07 dated September 26, 2007 and subsequent circulars.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Overseas Investments in Half Yearly Portfolio Statements
content.checklist_description: Overseas investments must be disclosed in half yearly portfolio statements under a separate heading 'Foreign Securities and/or overseas ETF(s)', including scheme-wise percentage of investments as a footnote in half yearly results.
content.rationale: To maintain transparency and provide detailed information on overseas investments to investors, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/IMD/CIR No.7/104753/07 dated September 26, 2007.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investment in Units of REITs/InvITs
content.checklist_description: For existing schemes investing in units of REITs/InvITs, the SID must disclose compliance with Regulation 18 (15A) of SEBI (Mutual Funds) Regulations, 1996, and unit holders must be informed about the exit option with a minimum 15-day period.
content.rationale: To ensure investors are informed about investments in REITs/InvITs and their rights, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF2/CIR/P/2017/17 dated February 28, 2017.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investment Restrictions
content.checklist_description: All investment restrictions as contained in the SEBI (Mutual Funds) Regulations, 1996, particularly the Seventh Schedule, must be disclosed and adhered to at the time of making investments.
content.rationale: To ensure compliance with regulatory investment limits and protect investor interests, as per SEBI Circular No. MFD/CIR/09/014/2000 dated January 5, 2000.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Investment Decision Process and Due Diligence
content.checklist_description: AMCs must disclose that due diligence and care are exercised in all investment decisions, maintain records supporting each investment decision including data, facts, and opinions, and report compliance with these requirements in periodical reports to Trustees and investors.
content.rationale: To ensure accountability and transparency in investment decisions, as per SEBI Circular No. MFD/CIR/6/73/2000 dated July 27, 2000.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Cumulative Gross Exposure Limits
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose that the cumulative gross exposure through equity, debt, derivatives, repo transactions, CDS, REITs, InvITs, and other permitted securities shall not exceed 100% of the net assets of the scheme.
content.rationale: To inform investors about exposure limits and risk management, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF2/CIR/P/2021/024 dated March 4, 2021.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Derivative Investment Norms and Risks
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the mutual fund's policy on derivatives including restrictions on writing options (except covered call strategy), exposure limits on option premiums (not exceeding 20% of net assets), and risks associated with derivatives and hedging strategies.
content.rationale: To provide investors with clear information on derivative usage and associated risks, as per SEBI Circular No. Cir/IMD/DF/11/2010 dated August 18, 2010 and subsequent circulars.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Covered Call Option Strategy
content.checklist_description: For schemes intending to write covered call options, the SID must disclose the risks and benefits of the strategy, including limits on notional value (15% of equity shares held) and number of shares underlying call options (30% of unencumbered shares).
content.rationale: To ensure investors understand the covered call strategy and associated risks, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF2/CIR/P/2019/17 dated January 16, 2019.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Interest Rate Hedging Using Interest Rate Futures (IRFs)
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the use of IRFs for hedging interest rate risk, including the extent of hedging, conditions for imperfect hedging, associated risks, and impact on scheme characteristics.
content.rationale: To inform investors about interest rate risk management and related risks, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF2/CIR/P/2017/109 dated September 27, 2017.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Derivative Positions in Portfolio Statements and Reports
content.checklist_description: Mutual funds must disclose derivative positions including hedging through IRFs and IRS in monthly and half yearly portfolio statements, annual reports, and on their websites, with details as per prescribed formats.
content.rationale: To maintain transparency and provide detailed derivative exposure information to investors, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF2/CIR/P/2021/024 dated March 4, 2021.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Participation in Credit Default Swaps (CDS)
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose the intention to participate in CDS transactions as protection buyers, related risks, and compliance with RBI and SEBI guidelines. Details of CDS transactions must be disclosed in monthly portfolio statements, half yearly trustee reports, and annual reports.
content.rationale: To enable investors to make informed decisions regarding CDS participation and ensure regulatory compliance, as per SEBI Circular No. CIR/IMD/DF/23/2012 dated November 15, 2012.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Trade Execution and Allocation Policies
content.checklist_description: AMCs must disclose their written policies detailing roles and responsibilities in order placement, execution, and trade allocation ensuring fair and equitable treatment of schemes and investors. The policies must include use of Order Management Systems (OMS), audit trails, and compliance monitoring.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency, fairness, and accountability in trade execution and allocation, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF2/CIR/P/2020/175 dated September 17, 2020.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Inter Scheme Transfer (IST) Policies and Safeguards
content.checklist_description: The SID must disclose policies and safeguards related to ISTs, including conditions under which ISTs are allowed, pricing at prevailing market price on spot basis, compliance with investment objectives, and documentation maintained to ensure regulatory compliance.
content.rationale: To prevent misuse of ISTs and protect investor interests, as per SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/DF4/CIR/P/2020/202 dated October 8, 2020.

content.checklist_title: Disclosure of Advertisement Requirements for Dividend Payouts
content.checklist_description: Advertisements must disclose dividends declared or paid in rupees per unit along with the face value of each unit and prevailing NAV at the time of declaration. For closed-ended or interval schemes, advertisements must state that the entire distributable surplus at maturity or interval completion will be distributed. Dividend/bonus payout advertisements must disclose that NAV will fall to the extent of payout and statutory levy.
content.rationale: To ensure clarity and transparency in dividend-related advertisements, preventing misleading information, as per SEBI Circular No. Cir/IMD/DF/6/2012 dated February 28, 2012.

content.checklist_title: Performance Disclosure in SID
content.checklist_description: Disclose the performance of the Mutual Fund scheme in terms of CAGR for the past 1 year, 3 years, 5 years, and since inception. Additionally, provide point-to-point returns on a standard investment of Rs. 10,000/- alongside CAGR to aid retail investor understanding. Specify whether the performance relates to the regular or direct plan, including a footnote about differing expense structures. If the scheme has had multiple fund managers during the period, disclose this fact in a footnote.
content.rationale: To ensure transparency and provide investors with standardized, comparable performance data, enabling informed investment decisions.

content.checklist_title: Performance Disclosure for New Schemes
content.checklist_description: If the scheme has been in existence for less than six months, do not provide past performance. If the scheme is between six months and one year old, disclose the simple annualized growth rate for the past six months from the last day of the month-end preceding the date of advertisement.
content.rationale: To avoid misleading investors with insufficient performance history and provide relevant performance metrics for new schemes.
